channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Amid Signs of Troop Shortages, Russia Aims to Expand Recruitment Pool
item.description: Moscow is moving toward dropping age limits for military service, stepping up its recruitment drive as it tries to score victories in Ukraine’s east after a series of setbacks.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A home destroyed by bombardment in the village of Vilkhivka, near Kharkiv, Ukraine. The village had been occupied for weeks by Russian forces.

item.title: As China Doubles Down on Lockdowns, Some Chinese Seek an Exit
item.description: Inquiries to immigration consultants have surged; social media users trade tips on how to get abroad. But the government aims to “strictly restrict nonessential exit activities.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: At Pudong International Airport in Shanghai last year. There are signs that China will continue to discourage overseas travel even once pandemic rules are relaxed.

item.title: Biden Begins Trip to Asia Meant to Reassure Allies of Focus on China
item.description: With the administration’s attention having shifted to Ukraine, President Biden plans to emphasize that the United States can counter aggression in both Europe and Asia.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden departing for South Korea on Thursday. Mr. Biden’s first trip to Asia will pose diplomatic challenges on several fronts.

item.title: Prince Charles and Camilla Visit Canada, Confronting Legacy of the Crown
item.description: Prince Charles acknowledged the “suffering” of the Indigenous community in a visit to the Northwest Territories on the last day of his three-day tour of the country, where polls suggest there is little support for the monarchy.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: How a Group of Female Independents Aims to Revive Australian Democracy
item.description: A community-driven movement has recruited around 25 candidates, most of them successful women preaching pragmatic reform. They could shape the balance of power after Saturday’s election.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Stephanie Simcox for The New York Times
item.media:description: Allegra Spender, an independent candidate for the Australian federal Parliament, is part of a movement aiming to save Australian democracy from the creep of corruption, right-wing populism and misogyny.

item.title: In Hungary, Cheap Russian Oil Fuels Right-Wing Culture Wars
item.description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban has resisted a proposed E.U. embargo of Russian oil, saying it would devastate his country’s economy, but it would also cut off a source of funds for his political allies.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Benjamin Novak
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Danube Refinery, owned by the Hungarian energy conglomerate MOL, south of Budapest. MOL said last month that it would pay out $652 million in dividends to shareholders.

item.title: ‘Wagatha Christie’ Case Offers a Riveting Peek Into Celebrity Culture
item.description: Libel proceedings in London have laid bare the personal lives of two British celebrities in a legal whodunit for the social media age. And it wasn’t just the tabloids that became obsessed with the feud.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Left, Dan Kitwood/Getty Images; Andy Rain/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Rebekah Vardy, left, and Coleen Rooney have both leveraged their exposure as the wives of famous soccer players to build huge social media followings and become well known in their own right.

item.title: Israeli Government Loses Parliament Majority, Raising Prospect of Election
item.description: Increasing tensions between Israeli authorities and Palestinians have put pressure on the government, leading to the possibility of a fifth election in three years.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Israel’s Parliament reopened in Jerusalem last week. A vote to bring down the government could come as early as next week.

item.title: An Indian State Banned Alcohol. The Drinking Moved to Nearby Nepal.
item.description: The ban in Bihar State, championed by local women, was aimed at tackling alcoholism and domestic violence. But a drinking scene has sprung up across the border in Nepal.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Bhadra Sharma
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sharing food and drinks at a bar in Mahottari, Nepal, just across the border with India.

item.title: The 17th-Century English Judge Behind Abortion and Rape Rulings Today
item.description: Both in India and in the Roe v. Wade draft ruling roiling the United States, Lord Matthew Hale — an English judge who wrote that women were contractually obligated to husbands — still looms large.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Universal History Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The 17th-century English jurist Lord Matthew Hale was cited in a recent Supreme Court draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade.

item.title: Chinese Hackers Tried to Steal Russian Defense Data, Report Says
item.description: The campaign detailed by a cybersecurity firm highlights Beijing’s increasingly sophisticated tactics to spy on an array of targets, including countries it considers friends.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Russian Defense Ministry in Moscow.

item.title: In Ukraine, Gruesome Injuries and Not Enough Doctors to Treat Them
item.description: Operating with skeleton crews, doctors and nurses race to save limbs, and lives. It’s a grim routine for medical personnel often working around the clock. And not all limbs can be saved.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario

item.title: Japanese Man Gambles Away a Town’s Covid Funds
item.description: An official in the rural Japanese town wired the 24-year-old man nearly $360,000 by mistake. He lost it in online casinos. Now, the town is suing and he has been arrested.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Abu, Japan, is about 100 miles north of the nearest major city, Fukuoka, in an area of Yamaguchi Prefecture where agriculture, fishing and forestry drive the economy.

item.title: Around Kharkiv, Ukrainians Emerge to Find Lives in Ruin
item.description: After sheltering underground since February, residents of the beseiged city have finally been able to to assess the damage the Russians left behind. The discoveries have been grisly.
item.dc:creator: Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:description: The wreckage of a market that was bombed in the Saltivka neighborhood in the eastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv.

item.title: A New Kind of Drug
item.description: How the country’s drug problem is changing, and why it’s growing.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elizabeth Cheryl Dillender and her daughter, Kristin. Their relative died of a fentanyl overdose last year.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Hungary’s thirst for Russian oil.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Hungarian oil refinery.

item.title: Officials Report a Possible Monkeypox Case in New York
item.description: The patient is under care at Bellevue Hospital while further testing is conducted.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein
item.media:credit: Russell Regnery/Cdc Cynthia S. Goldsmith/Via Reuters
item.media:description: An electron microscopic image shows mature, oval-shaped monkeypox virus particles.

item.title: Russian Rock Singer Charged After Condemning the Ukraine War
item.description: The singer made the comments less than three months after Russia enacted a law that would punish spreading “false information” about its invasion.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuri Shevchuk, lead singer of the Russian band DDT, in the band’s recording studio in St. Petersburg, Russia, in 2010.

item.title: Prince Charles Dances With Indigenous People to End Canada Visit
item.description: On the prince’s third and final day in Canada, he said he was “deeply moved’’ by the stories of those who survived brutal treatment in residential schools.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.media:description: A traditional drum demonstration was held for Prince Charles during a visit with the Dettah Community of the Yellowknives Dene First Nation on Thursday.

item.title: Moscow Moves to Russify Seized Ukraine Land, Signaling Annexation
item.description: The territory occupied by Russian forces so far in the three-month-old invasion deserves “a worthy place in our Russian family,” a Kremlin official who toured the region said.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: A Russian military vehicle in Mariupol, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Seeks Swift Effort to Bring Finland and Sweden Into NATO
item.description: Speedy approval seems likely among most members of the alliance in the wake of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but Turkey’s objections remain a sticking point.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times

item.title: Ukrainian Oligarch Mulls Selling Superyacht to Distance Himself From Russia
item.description: The richest man in Ukraine has committed to building back his country. But he is also constructing a luxury ship that would rival a yacht that the U.S. government believes may belong to Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Michael Forsythe

item.title: Russian Gymnast Who Wore Pro-War ‘Z’ Symbol on Podium Is Given One-Year Ban
item.description: The gymnast, Ivan Kuliak, wore the symbol while standing at the podium next to the Ukrainian gold medalist.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia Seeks More Control Over Occupied Ukraine
item.description: Plus the war is causing hunger in Africa and the “teals” are looking to upend Australia’s elections.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Homes destroyed by bombardment in the village of Vilkhivka on Thursday.

item.title: New Evidence Shows How Russian Soldiers Executed Men in Bucha
item.description: Witness testimony and videos obtained by The New York Times show how Russian paratroopers executed at least eight Ukrainian men in a Kyiv suburb on March 4, a potential war crime.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Evan Hill, Malachy Browne and David Botti
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Navalny’s Team Lobbies Congress to Place More Sanctions on Putin’s Associates
item.description: The activists are pitching sanctions on midlevel officials as a cost-free way for the United States to further isolate the Russian president.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei Navalny appeared via video link before a court hearing in Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: A Russian Official Tours Occupied Southern Ukraine
item.description: The official, Marat Khusnullin, Russia’s deputy prime minister for infrastructure, outlined plans to take control of vital infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A photograph taken during a trip organized by the Russian military showed Russian vehicles driving by the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Station in Enerhodar, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine, Bridget Brink, Has Experience Shaped By Soviet Domination
item.description: Bridget Brink has worked in Slovakia, Uzbekistan and Georgia. She is filling a role that has been empty for three years.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Bridget Brink in Washington earlier this month during her testimony before the Senate on her nomination as ambassador to Ukraine.

item.title: The Senate Approves $40 Billion in New Aid to Ukraine
item.description: The measure’s smooth path through Congress reflected a broad consensus on Capitol Hill, for now, to devote massive sums to supporting Ukraine’s war effort with little debate.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A home was destroyed by Russian forces in Vilkhivka, Ukraine. The Senate gave approval to the largest foreign aid package passed by Congress in at least two decades.

item.title: Former German Chancellor Loses Perks Over Ties to Russia
item.description: The former German leader, a personal friend of President Vladimir V. Putin and lobbyist for Russian energy companies, has refused to distance himself from Russia.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Gerhard Schöder, a former German chancellor, will lose many of his post-chancellor perks after declining to distance himself from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: Russian Soldier Who Pleaded Guilty at War Crimes Trial Apologizes
item.description: Sgt. Vadim Shishimarin says he was ordered to shoot at 62-year-old Oleksandr Shelipov because he and his fellow soldiers believed that he was informing the Ukrainian military about their location.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vadim Shishimarin, in court in Kyiv on Wednesday, pleaded guilty to killing a 62-year-old man.

item.title: Juan Carlos, Former King, Returns to Spain
item.description: The former monarch left his country in the wake of fraud investigations, which have since been dropped, and now lives in the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.media:description: Juan Carlos, the former Spanish monarch, center, with his wife, Sofía, right, in Madrid in 2018.

item.title: Scientists Uncover a Shady Web of Online Spider Sales
item.description: More than 1,200 species of arachnids are part of a largely unregulated global marketplace, according to a new study.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.media:description: A captive cobalt blue tarantula, Haplopelma lividum.

item.title: Livestreams of Mass Shootings: From Buffalo to New Zealand
item.description: Dozens of recordings of a 2019 massacre in Christchurch, New Zealand, remain online, in a sobering reminder of the internet’s permanence.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Kellen Browning and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Joshua Rashaad McFadden for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial outside a Tops Friendly Market in Buffalo, N.Y., after a mass shooting last weekend. The gunman took inspiration from a 2019 rampage in Christchurch, New Zealand, videos of which continue circulating.

item.title: G7 Finance Ministers Race to Secure More Ukraine Aid
item.description: Officials are working on a plan to provide $15 billion to help keep Ukraine’s government operating during its war with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal of Ukraine remotely joined a meeting of finance ministers from the Group of 7 near Bonn, Germany, on Thursday.

item.title: Boris Johnson Avoids Further Fines as the Police End Lockdown Inquiry
item.description: The completion of the investigation into parties at Downing Street that violated Covid rules lifts a cloud over the prime minister’s political future.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: 10 Downing Street, where the British prime minister lives and works, in January. A report is expected to cast a harsh light on the alcohol-fueled culture there.

item.title: Coping With ‘Zero Covid’
item.description: Our correspondent takes you inside Shanghai’s Covid lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: Covid testing at a residential compound in Shanghai yesterday.

item.title: U.S. Eyeing Russian Energy Sanctions Over Ukraine War, Officials Say
item.description: The revenue powers Vladimir V. Putin’s war machine in Ukraine. But plans for new U.S. sanctions could create problems with China, India and other major buyers.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Gazprom Neft’s oil refinery in Moscow. New restrictions on Russian energy sales have greater potential for long-term damage to the country’s economy.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Turkey’s efforts to delay Finland’s and Sweden’s NATO applications.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan has criticized Sweden as a haven for Kurdish separatists whom he sees as terrorists.

item.title: Russia Uses Surrender in Mariupol to Portray Ukrainians as Terrorists
item.description: Many soldiers who surrendered from Mariupol’s Azovstal steel plant belong to the Azov battalion, a group with far-right roots, and the Kremlin may now put them on trial just as Ukraine is prosecuting Russians for war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Neil MacFarquhar, Ivan Nechepurenko and Michael Levenson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A photo taken during a trip organized by the Russian Ministry of Defense shows Russian soldiers in a destroyed part of a Mariupol factory on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Turkey’s NATO Block
item.description: Plus North Korea’s Covid strategy and China’s expanding internet censorship.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus
item.media:credit: Johanna Geron/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Finland and Sweden submitted their NATO applications on Wednesday morning.

item.title: The World Is as Vulnerable as Ever to Pandemics, an Expert Panel Concludes
item.description: The authors of the new report zeroed in on the uneven distribution of vaccines around the world as one of the major hurdles to overcome.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Health care workers giving a coronavirus vaccine at a home in Colombo, Sri Lanka, in March.

item.title: Strongmen in Turkey and Hungary Stall Unity in NATO and the E.U.
item.description: Russia benefits as Turkey slows down Swedish and Finnish applications to NATO and Hungary continues to block an E.U. embargo on Russian oil.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has criticized Sweden as a haven for Kurdish separatists whom he sees as terrorists.

item.title: Biden Endorses Finland and Sweden’s Bids to Join NATO
item.description: Mr. Biden’s pledge is far short of a treaty, or even an executive agreement committing the United States to come to the aid of both countries.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden timed his statement to precede a visit to the White House on Thursday by Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson of Sweden and President Sauli Niinisto of Finland.

item.title: Stop Picking Endangered Phallic Plant, Cambodia Warns
item.description: In Cambodia, video of women suggestively joking around with a protected carnivorous specimen prompted a government admonition: Hands off, people.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:description: The Nepenthes gracilis, a carnivorous plant, at an exhibition in Colombia in 2018. The Nepenthes genus is distinctive for an elongated receptacle, a pitcher, with a lid that closes and trap insects inside.

item.title: U.K. Lawmaker Reportedly Arrested Over Rape Allegations
item.description: The arrest, of a man who has not yet been identified, was the latest in a string of sexual misconduct allegations against members of Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The reported arrest of a British lawmaker comes on the heels of a number of troubling incidents in Parliament.

item.title: Russian Soldier Pleads Guilty in Kyiv to Violating ‘Laws and Customs of War’
item.description: Sgt. Vadim Shyshimarin, 21, admitted in a Ukrainian court he had fatally shot a 62-year-old man on a bicycle in the village in the Sumy region in the early days of the invasion. He faces 10 years to life in prison.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Sgt. Vadim Shishimarin, 21, at a court hearing in Kyiv on Wednesday. He pleaded guilty to shooting a man in the Sumy region of Ukraine early in the war.

item.title: John Fetterman: ‘Unfussy and Plain-Spoken’
item.description: John Fetterman, the Democratic Senate nominee in Pennsylvania, isn’t like most politicians in his party.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Fetterman in Pennsylvania this month.

item.title: Economic Headwinds Mount as Leaders Weigh Costs of Confronting Russia
item.description: Top economic officials are gathering this week to discuss how to keep pressure on Vladimir V. Putin without sinking their economies.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: Refugees fleeing the war in Ukraine arrived in Przemsyl, Poland, in March. The conflict is taking an economic toll on Poland, which has absorbed more than three million refugees.

item.title: China-Style Covid Lockdowns Risk Deepening North Korean Crisis
item.description: As infections spread quickly, outside experts are warning that the country’s desire to mimic Beijing’s playbook could worsen a coming disaster.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media showed North Korean leader Kim Jong-un attending a meeting on anti-virus strategies in Pyongyang, North Korea last week.

item.title: Do Airline Offset Programs Really Reduce Your Carbon Footprint?
item.description: Carbon credits could eventually play an important role in fighting climate change, but right now a few dollars’ worth won’t change much.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
item.media:description: Offsets seek to compensate for greenhouse gas emissions in one place by funding emissions reductions or carbon removal somewhere else.

item.title: ‘I could not stay away’: With Russians pushed back, residents return to Kharkiv.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daryna Mostyvskaya hugging her mother, Lyudmyla Mostyvskaya, who returned to Kharkiv, Ukraine, by train on Tuesday.

item.title: Labour asks if Conservatives broke U.K. election laws by accepting a donation linked to a Russian account.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:credit: David M. Benett/Getty Images for Halcyon Art International
item.media:description: Ehud Sheleg, second left, at the 2019 Venice Biennale.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The surrender of Ukrainian forces in Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers, who had held out for weeks at the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol, were evacuated on Tuesday. They are now in Russian custody and their futures are unclear.

item.title: Ukrainian Holdouts in Mariupol Surrender to an Uncertain Fate
item.description: The government’s order for hundreds of remaining fighters to stand down offers Russia a propaganda victory, but prospects for a prisoner swap seem unclear at best.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Rick Gladstone
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen in a bus after they were evacuated from Mariupol’s besieged Azovstal steel plant on Tuesday. They are now in Russian custody and their futures are unclear.

item.title: Russian Hacking Cartel Attacks Costa Rican Government Agencies
item.description: Experts who track the hackers’ actions said the group had recently begun to shift its focus to countries in Central and South America, perhaps as retaliation against nations that have supported Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and David Bolaños
item.media:description: Hackers claiming to be affiliated with Conti broke into Costa Rica’s Ministry of Finance, the government said, and from there the ransomware spread to other agencies.

item.title: Biden Administration Offers Venezuela Minor Sanctions Relief
item.description: The Biden administration said it would relax restrictions on Chevron’s dealings with President Nicolás Maduro and remove sanctions from his relative.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela during a May Day rally in Caracas, this month.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Sri Lanka, Out of Fuel
item.description: Plus lockdowns continue in Shanghai, and India’s community health workers press for a raise.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up for fuel in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Tuesday.

item.title: Europe Rethinks Its Reliance on Burning Wood for Electricity
item.description: A new proposal would significantly rewrite E.U. rules on renewable energy, ending subsidies for biomass like wood pellets.
item.dc:creator: Lois Parshley
item.media:description: A biomass power plant in Pontevedra, Spain.
